After the Bodhisattva Dharmodgata has enjoyed himself with the court ladies, he expounds the perfection of wisdom three times a day.
In the city of Fragrant Incense, the men and women, young and old, in the city gather in the most crowded places and set up a great Dharma seat.
The seat has four legs, made of either gold, silver, lapis lazuli, or crystal, covered with soft cushions of various colors, with curtains and tassels hanging down;
He covered it with fine white cotton cloth, scattered various wonderful flowers and incense on top,

On the four sides of the pond, he scattered flowers of five colors, burned various famous incense, and anointed the ground with fragrant oil, in order to make offerings and pay respect to the perfection of wisdom.

those people made offerings and paid respect to Dharmodgata in this way, in order to hear the perfection of wisdom.

In this great assembly of hundreds of thousands and millions, the devas and humans of the world gathered together in one place. Some listened, some received it, some upheld it, some recited it, some wrote it, some contemplated it correctly, and some practiced it as explained.

You, good man,

Good man,
the bodhisattva Dharmodgata has been your good friend in life after life, able to teach you supreme, perfect enlightenment, showing, teaching, benefiting, and delighting you.
When the bodhisattva Dharmodgata originally sought the perfection of wisdom, it was also like how you are now.

The Treatise asks:
Why did Sadaprarudita forget and not ask the voice in the sky?
Answer:
Because Sadaprarudita was overjoyed and his mind was overwhelmed, he forgot;
Just as a person who is greatly worried or greatly delighted forgets because of these two things.
Question:
Since the voice in the sky has already disappeared, why did he stay there for seven days and not seek further to ask about it?
Answer:
Just as before, he was seeking prajÃ±Ä with a single mind in a secluded place, and a voice appeared in the sky;
Now he also wants to single-mindedly be as before, hoping to hear the voice again and resolve his doubts.
Furthermore, Sadaprarudita has already abandoned worldly pleasures and deeply entered the Buddha's path, with sincere affection;
The voice in the sky briefly revealed a little, but his doubts were not yet resolved, and the voice then disappeared.
It is like a child who obtains a little delicious food, and because of being attached to that taste, he cries even more, wanting to get it again;
SadÄprarudita was also like this. He obtained the flavor of the causes and conditions of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, but was unable to penetrate it and did not know where to go, therefore he stayed and wept.
Question:
Why did the Buddha's body appear after seven days?
Answer:
It is like when a person is very thirsty, so they know water is delicious.
If it were two or three days, their diligence and desire would not be deep;
if it were more than seven days, they would be worried that sorrow would hinder their mind and they would not be able to seek the Way.
Therefore they were sorrowful for seven days.
As it is said in the Parable Sutra.
Question:
Why was SadÄprarudita's sorrow so great, like losing a beloved child?
Answer:
PrajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the foremost truth among all dharmas. It is the true Dharma treasure of the Buddhas of the ten directions;
SadÄprarudita obtained a small taste of it, but because it was not complete, he was sorrowful.
It is like a parent who has lost a beloved child, thinking of how the child grew up and accomplished many things, hoping to get the child's strength;
Bodhisattvas are also like this, thinking of the power of increasing the perfection of wisdom, attaining irreversibility, and accomplishing the Buddha's work.
It is like a child who is filial to his parents throughout his life, without a different mind;
The perfection of wisdom is also like this for bodhisattvas. If they can enter it, up to becoming a Buddha, they will never be separated from it.
It is like a parent who sees their child and is immediately delighted;
Even though bodhisattvas attain various dharmas, it is not as joyful as seeing the perfection of wisdom.
It is like a child being given a name;
The perfection of wisdom is also like this. It is empty and has no fixed reality, but only has a provisional name.
These are the general characteristics of the causes and conditions.
Although a parent loves their child, they cannot give them their head or eyes;
For the sake of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, bodhisattvas, for innumerable eons, give their heads, eyes, marrow, and brains to sentient beings.
A child may not be able to repay their parents' kindness, but if they can repay their parents' kindness, it is only a small benefit in this world, such as clothing, food, and happiness.
In prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ, bodhisattvas obtain everything up to omniscience, let alone the power and worldly wealth and happiness of bodhisattvas.
A child's repayment of their parents' kindness is limited to one lifetime.
The benefits of prajÃ±Ä extend to innumerable lifetimes, up to becoming a buddha.
A child may love or hate their parents;
prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is free from all that is unacceptable.
A child is merely a nominal, false, and unreal dharma;
prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is a true and real holy dharma, free from falsehood.
Although a child's repayment of their parents' kindness may bring them a little happiness in this world, it also brings immeasurable suffering of worry and distress;
PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ only brings about the joy and true happiness up to the bliss of the Buddha.
A son can only benefit his father by making offerings, but cannot save him from birth, old age, sickness, and death;
PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ enables bodhisattvas to be ultimately pure, without the afflictions of old age, sickness, and death.
A son can only enable his father to attain worldly happiness and freedom;
PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ enables bodhisattvas to be the lord of devas and humans in all worlds.
In this way, there are various causes and conditions and distinctions in analogies.
Because worldly people all know the sorrow of losing a child, this is used as a metaphor.
Question:
What kind of Buddha is manifested in the sky?
Why was there only a sound before and now a manifestation of the body?
Since the Buddha has already manifested his body, why did he not immediately save him but instead sent him to Dharmodgata?
Answer:
Some say:
It is not a real Buddha, but only a reflected image - either sent by the Buddhas or manifested by great bodhisattvas.
Because their past wholesome roots and merits have not yet been accomplished, they only hear the sound;
Now, for seven days and seven nights, they single-mindedly think of the Buddha, and because their merits are accomplished, they get to see the Buddha's body.
The reason the Buddha does not immediately deliver them is because their karmic connection with Dharmodgata from lifetime to lifetime should be delivered by him.
There are people who should be delivered by ÅšÄriputra, and even if the Buddhas manifest their bodies, they cannot cause them to awaken.

The Buddha praises them as excellent because SadÄprarudita seeks to know the whereabouts and hears the causes and conditions of prajÃ±Ä with utmost sincerity, so the Buddha manifests his body and praises them as excellent.
The Buddhas of the past, when practicing the bodhisattva path, also sought this prajÃ±Ä in this way, with various hardships;
Because they first gave rise to the mind, but their past sins were heavy and their merits and virtues had not yet accumulated.
The Buddha comforts their minds:
Although you seek prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ with hardship, do not be lazy, do not give rise to a mind of retreat!
The practices of all sentient beings are different. At the time of the causes, they all suffer, but when they receive the fruits, they are happy.
You should contemplate the immeasurable merits and fruits of the Buddhas and encourage yourself.
Having comforted him like this, he said:
You should go east from here. After five hundred yojanas, there is a city called Fragrant. Before long, you will hear prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Question:
Where is the Fragrant City?
Answer:

After the extinction of the Buddhas of the past, there are only remaining teachings. These teachings are not universally spread throughout JambudvÄ«pa. Sentient beings go to places where there are conditions to hear the Dharma.
At that time, the land of Fragrant was prosperous and happy, and produced the seven treasures in abundance. Therefore, the city was made of the seven treasures.

At that time, although SadÄprarudita was in JambudvÄ«pa, he was born in a place without the Buddha's teachings and without the seven treasures. He only heard the Buddha's name and that prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ is the Buddha's path.

This person had accumulated vast merit and virtue in previous lives, and his afflictions were slight. Therefore, upon hearing [the teachings], he immediately believed and delighted in them, detested worldly pleasures, abandoned his relatives, went to live in an empty forest, and wished to go to a country where there was the Buddha's teaching.
The voice that instructed him was afraid that he would go elsewhere and not reach where the bodhisattva Dharmodgata was, so it spoke to him;
Subsequently, the Buddha manifested his body and showed him the way to go.
Question:

Answer:

This bodhisattva, in the city of Fragrant Incense, for the sake of sentient beings, spoke the Dharma according to their inclinations, enabling sentient beings to extensively plant roots of goodness, and was therefore called Dharma Prosperity.
That country had no king, and the people there had no sense of self, like the people of Uttarakuru. They only took the bodhisattva Dharmodgata as their king.
That country was difficult to reach, but SadÄprarudita, not sparing his life, and also receiving the assistance of the buddhas and bodhisattvas, was able to reach it.
Great bodhisattvas, in order to save sentient beings, are born in such countries;
because sentient beings have nothing lacking, their minds are subdued and pliable, and are easily saved.
Question:
Is the bodhisattva Dharmodgata a born body?
Or is he a Dharma body, who, in order to save sentient beings, manifests this body through the power of spiritual penetrations?
If it is a transformed body, why does he enjoy himself with sixty thousand court ladies, gardens, ponds, and various adornments?
If it was his physical body, how could it cause Satata SamÄ«ká¹£aá¹‡Ä's offerings to all transform into a great platform in the sky and enter various samÄdhis for seven years?
Answer:
Some say:
This bodhisattva in his physical body, having attained the true characteristics of dharmas and the power of concentration and spiritual penetrations, wishes to deliver the beings in the city.
Like other bodhisattvas with sharp faculties, he is able to enter concentration and also able to enter the dharmas of the desire realm;
In order to gather beings, he accepts the five desires without losing his concentration.
It is like a person who, in order to avoid heat, lies down in the mud and then washes off, returning to normal.
Ordinary beings with dull faculties are not able to do so.
Therefore, by the power of spiritual penetrations, he transforms into a flower platform and enters concentration for seven years;
And by the power of skillful means, he is able to accept the five desires, as explained in the previous meaning.
The bodhisattva does not only practice one path, but for the sake of beings, he practices various paths to guide them.
It is like a dragon that can bring forth clouds, pour down heavy rain, thunder and lightning, and cause thunderous explosions;

Bodhisattvas are also like this. Although they have a physical body and have not yet escaped from afflictions, they are able to cultivate good dharmas and, for the sake of sentient beings, do not exhaust their afflictions.
Some people say:
This bodhisattva is born with the body of the Dharma-nature. In order to save the people of the city of Fragrant, he transforms and saves them.
If this is a physical body, how can he cause the Buddhas of the ten directions to praise him and send SadÄprarudita to receive the Dharma from him, and attain sixty thousand samÄdhis?
Therefore, we know that this is the transformed body of a great bodhisattva.
It is like when the death signs of a dragon in the great ocean appear, as if the fruit is ripe and about to fall, and the garuá¸a comes to eat it;
Sentient beings are also like this. Because the causes and conditions of their karmic actions are ripe, a great bodhisattva comes to save them.

At that time, SadÄprarudita, hearing the Buddha's teachings in the sky, was greatly delighted. Because the mind of great desire arose, he thought, When will I be able to see Bodhisattva Dharmodgata - the one who expounds the perfection of wisdom - who can draw out the arrows of afflictions such as love and views in my mind?
In order to clarify this matter, the Buddha here gives the analogy of a poisoned arrow:
It is like a person with a poisoned arrow in their body, who has no other thoughts:
First, the pain is urgent, and second, if the poison does not quickly come out, it will spread throughout the body and lead to death.
SadÄprarudita is also like this. The arrows of wrong views and doubts enter the mind, and the poisons of greed and so forth coat the arrows.
He hears that Bodhisattva Dharmodgata can pull out these arrows.

This person is wounded by the poisoned arrow of wrong views, and people fear that the poisons of greed and so forth will spread throughout the body, robbing the wisdom life and causing death, the same as an ordinary person.
Therefore, he urgently wanted to see Bodhisattva Dharmodgata, with no other thoughts.
Here it is said to cut off all existing minds.
As for existing minds, they grasp characteristics and become attached, even to good dharmas there is this illness.

SubhÅ«ti saw the Buddha's body, which he had never seen before, and heard the teachings from the Buddha. Because of the joy of the Dharma, he was free from the joy of the five desires, and immediately attained unobstructed knowledge and insight into all dharmas.
As for unobstructed knowledge and insight, it is like SubhÅ«ti's attainment of unobstructed power, not the Buddha's unobstructed [power].
At that time, he entered the various samÄdhi gates. As for the samÄdhi of observing the nature of all dharmas, it is able to observe the true nature of all dharmas.
As for the true nature, it is as explained above with various causes and conditions.
As for the samÄdhi of the unobtainability of the nature of all dharmas, one first attains samÄdhi, namely emptiness, non-arising, and non-extinction;
Now, having attained this samÄdhi, one is not attached to this nature and does not obtain its definitive characteristics.

The samÄdhi of destroying the ignorance of all dharmas means that due to the causes and conditions of ignorance, all dharmas in the minds of ordinary people are crooked and not upright, namely permanence, bliss, self, and purity;
Because one attains this samÄdhi, the ignorance corresponding to the inverted views of permanence, etc. is destroyed, and one only contemplates all dharmas as impermanent, empty, and without self.
Question:
If this bodhisattva destroys the ignorance in all dharmas, this person should not even need to see the Buddha, so why go to where the bodhisattva Dharmodgata is?
Answer:

Destroying ignorance is not of a single kind - there is obstruction that prevents it from arising, which is also called destruction, and there is the attainment of the true characteristics of all dharmas, therefore destroying ignorance.
Moreover, the types of ignorance are extremely numerous:
There are parts that are destroyed by bodhisattvas, parts that are destroyed by buddhas, parts that are destroyed by lesser bodhisattvas and parts that are destroyed by great bodhisattvas;
as explained above in the analogy of the lamp.
Moreover, a stream-enterer is also called one who destroys ignorance, up to an arhat who truly destroys it;

it is the same in the Mahayana teachings. A bodhisattva of newly arisen resolve who attains the true characteristics of dharmas is also called one who destroys ignorance, up to a buddha who completely destroys ignorance without remainder.

Therefore, since SadÄprarudita completely exhausted wrong views, ignorance, and the view of self in the Buddha's teachings, he is called one who attains the samÄdhi of destroying ignorance, without fault.ğŸ”½The samÄdhi of the non-differentiation of dharmas: Attaining this samÄdhi, one contemplates all dharmas as having a single characteristic, namely, the absence of characteristics.

The samÄdhi of the indestructibility and mastery of all dharmas: Attaining this samÄdhi, one contemplates all dharmas as having the characteristics of suchness, the nature of dharmas, and the ultimate reality, and is therefore called indestructible.
Having attained this Dharma, one attains mastery and clearly understands all dharmas;
But for the sake of Buddhahood, one does not realize this Dharma.
The samÄdhi of illuminating all dharmas means knowing all dharmas through their general and specific characteristics.
The samÄdhi of separating from darkness in all dharmas means there are two kinds of ignorance:
First, thick; second, thin.
Thin is called ignorance, thick is called darkness.
Separating from thick ignorance is called separating from darkness, first separating from thin ignorance is called destroying the ignorance of all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of the continuity of the non-differentiation of all dharmas means the five aggregates cease moment by moment, similar continuity arises, at death, continuity arises but is not similar.
Attaining this samÄdhi, one knows the continuity of the dharmas moment by moment, the Dharma is not different.
The samÄdhi of the non-attainability of all dharmas means it is the samÄdhi corresponding to the emptiness of all dharmas.
The SamÄdhi of Scattering Flowers means that one who attains this samÄdhi can scatter seven-jeweled flowers in front of the Buddhas of the ten directions.
The SamÄdhi of the Absence of a Self in All Dharmas means contemplating that all dharmas are without a self.
The SamÄdhi of Illusory Power means that one who attains this samÄdhi can transform his body in various ways.
Like a great magician, he can guide sentient beings to give rise to a rare state of mind;
like a great magician, by the power of his illusions, he can change the minds of the people of a country.

Attaining the SamÄdhi of Obtaining Images Like Reflections in a Mirror means that one who attains this samÄdhi contemplates all that exists in the three realms as being like reflections in a mirror, deceptive and unreal.
Attaining the SamÄdhi of the Language of All Sentient Beings means that because one attains this samÄdhi, one can understand the languages of all sentient beings.
The SamÄdhi of the Joy of All Sentient Beings means that by entering this samÄdhi, one can transform the angry minds of sentient beings and bring them joy.
Entering the samÄdhi of discerning sounds means that entering this samÄdhi, one is able to discern the relative loudness and softness, coarseness and subtlety, etc. of all heavenly and human sounds.

Attaining the samÄdhi of adorning language, words, and phrases with various expressions means that one who attains this samÄdhi, even though the meaning may be shallow, is able to adorn the words and phrases of the language, causing people to rejoice, let alone profound meanings!
The samÄdhi of fearlessness means that one who attains this samÄdhi is not afraid of any demons, non-Buddhist teachers, or afflictions.
The samÄdhi of always being silent by nature means that one who enters this samÄdhi always remains silent and focused;
in order to liberate sentient beings, one emits sounds in accordance with what they should hear, like heavenly music, which emerges in response to one's thoughts.
Attaining the samÄdhi of unobstructed liberation means that one who attains this samÄdhi attains unobstructed wisdom with regard to all dharmas.

The samÄdhi of leaving behind dust and defilements means that one who attains this samÄdhi extinguishes all afflictions, bonds, and defilements, which is precisely the samÄdhi of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The samÄdhi of adorning names, phrases, and sentences means that one who attains this samÄdhi is able to adorn verses, phrases, and language in various ways to expound the Dharma.
The samÄdhi of seeing all dharmas means that one who enters this samÄdhi, by seeing the truth of the world and the ultimate truth, knows all dharmas.
The samÄdhi of the unobstructed peak of all dharmas means that just as a person on the summit of a mountain surveys the four directions,
